title: self harming kids online trolls jane moore
story: She smoked (fags and pot), she drank alcohol (often in front of her liberal parents), always had what my mother would consider to be unsuitable boyfriends and was effortlessly academic, particularly at maths.Often, as we walked home from school chatting away, she would casually drag the back of her hand along a brick wall, causing the flesh to swell angrily and bleed.Other times she’d quietly press a lit cigarette into her palm, her expression never changing.“Why do you do that?” I’d ask.“It makes me feel better,” she’d say with a shrug.Sarah (not her real name) was, as I now know it, a self-harmer. But in those days — the late Seventies — it was rare and unrecognised.We lost touch a long time ago, but I thought of Sarah this week when I read that the number of teenage girls self-harming has doubled in the past 20 years.According to new NHS data, the number of hospital admissions for girls who have self-harmed has jumped from 7,327 in 1997 to 13,463 last year. For boys, the figures have stayed almost the same — from 2,236 then to 2,332 now.Worse, “self-poisoning” — as in taking an overdose — is rising for both genders and last month the Government released a green paper that said around 850,000 children and young people now have a diagnosable mental health condition.Experts say academic pressure is a contributory factor, so too social media.Kids have always had exams to cope with but in the old days jealous and bitter remarks were confined to the dark corners of secret conversations or, at worst, scrawled on a toilet wall.Now these brave warriors have a keyboard and pseudonym behind which they can troll you for everyone to see.By my age, you know the vitriol probably comes from a bitter, 53-year-old virgin who lives in his mother’s spare bedroom. But when you’re still finding your way in the world, that poisonous undermining can worm its way inside your head and chip away at the confidence that acts as an armour in life.One self-harmer told me the pain of cutting his skin provided a welcome distraction from the “washing machine” rotations of negative thoughts constantly disturbing his peace of mind.The majority of them can be helped if it is spotted early enough and the expert assistance they need is then easy to access. And therein lies the problem.In 2016, Theresa May said the mental health of children was to be one of her priorities as PM, but since then Brexit has taken over and little has changed.The Government’s strategy is to train more teachers to spot the signs, appoint 7,000 more specialists to child mental health units and cut the waiting time for non-critical cases to be seen.But even if it happens, it won’t be enough.Parents must also remain vigilant for any marked change in their child’s personality or behaviour and the big social media companies have the technology to stop the majority of trolls — so they should be forced to use it.If all of the above doesn’t happen, the NHS has another mental health time bomb coming which will cost the taxpayer a fortune and have an even greater cost to the mental well-being of the next generation.WHEN TV baker Paul Hollywood started dating a 23-year-old barmaid from his local pub, they were quick to point out that their relationship only started after his marriage to wife Alex ended.But Alex is reportedly not buying this explanation and is planning to name Summer Monteys-Fullam in her £10million divorce battle.Whatever the truth, it remains the case that many couples conveniently consider only full sexual intercourse as adultery.But of course, cosy chats, lingering touches and come-hither looks are all it takes for any man with a wandering eye to recognise that, should he wish to jump ship, there’s a shiny new model waiting in the wings to rev up his sex life.Hallelujah for the wonderfully pragmatic Emma Thompson who, when asked about her marriage to the dreamily handsome Greg Wise, replied that they have had plenty of rough times.The secret to a happy relationship, she says, is the realisation that there will be unhappy times and that, if you manage to amble through to the other side: “It’s always better.”She adds: “I think people in long, happy marriages tell a lot of fibs, like, ‘Yes, it’s been marvellous’, whereas I say, ‘Sometimes it has been awful’.”If a relationship is deeply unhappy for a sustained period then, of course, get the hell out.But in these Tinder times of endlessly sweeping left in search of the “perfect” mate (who doesn’t exist) it’s invaluable when someone high profile points out that, more often than not, sticking with the one you’ve got works out in the end.Altogether now, “Love is a decision, not just a feeling.”Daisy-May Demetres smile lights up a room.Just eight years old, she was born without her lower legs and now uses two prosthetic blades that allow her to live as full a life as possible.She attends mainstream school, loves PE and has just been given a modelling contract with high street brand River Island.Yet, because of her disability, her parents Alex and Claire admit to feeling a “profound sadness” the day she was born and asked themselves what they had done wrong. And when, as a toddler, Daisy-May had to endure a painful, eight-hour operation on her stumps, Alex admits he turned to alcohol and gambling in a bid to numb his feelings of hopelessness.But by the time she was four, Daisy-May had mastered her blades and was doing cartwheels and headstands.Alex, 35, from Birmingham, says: “I looked at her and thought, ‘If you can achieve so much, against all the odds, and still be cheerful, then I have no reason at all to be depressed’. I stopped gambling and drinking that day.”While no one would wish disability on their child, the Demetres’ story is a salutary lesson that, sometimes, what seems like insurmountable adversity through an adult’s eyes can, through a child’s simple acceptance and joie de vivre, enrich your life and give it deeper meaning.Following a cyber attack in Alaska, government officials have abandoned their computers and taken to using old-fashioned typewriters.Let joy be unconfined.I still have my original typewriter from my days as a junior reporter on the Solihull News and it was a loyal servant that never crashed, froze or ran out of battery. I may even request for it to be buried with me.It seems that my love for these machines is rivalled only by Tom Hanks (yes, that one) who has written a book of short stories about them and created an app called the Hanx Writer, which emulates the glorious click-clack sound as you type.Go on, try it. There’s no greater pleasure.No? Just me then...Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa mays public sector wage hikes leaves tens of thousands of public sector workers with less take home pay
story: Experts last night said nurses and teachers were among those facing huge disappointment despite increases billed as the “biggest for a decade” by the Government just weeks ago.The pay hikes have moved certain workers into a higher pension contribution band – meaning the state takes more towards their retirement.Insurer Royal London said an employee on £26,500 who gets a 2 per cent pay hike could have as much as £146 a year less in their pocket to spend because their pension contributions move from 7.1 per cent to 9.3 per cent.One NHS source said a number of young nurses were shocked to see their most recent pay packet go DOWN.Others had seen an increase of as little as 60p a month.She said: “People recognise the NHS pension is a rare golden one.“But for many young families this has impacted their current lives. No one mentioned the wider implications of this pay rise.”The revelation comes just a day after the BMA union warned that 90 per cent of doctors were unhappy with their pay deal.Theresa May ripped up the seven-year public sector pay cap earlier this year by awarding NHS staff a 6 per cent pay rise over 3 years.Big hikes of up to 3.5 per cent were then announced for doctors, teachers, prison guards, police officers and the Armed Forces last month.Steve Webb, the ex-Lib Dem pensions minister and now Royal London policy chief, said: “Millions of nurses, teachers and other public servants have faced nearly a decade of pay squeezes and will have believed that things were finally going to get better.“It was unforgiveable not to explain that increased pension contributions could mean some of them would actually be worse off following the new pay deal.”A Treasury spokesman last night said: “It’s right that as workers earn more money they contribute a bit more towards their public sector pensions – which continue to be some of the most generous pensions available.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour jeremy corbyn brexit
story: A nationwide campaign will be launched next week urging activists to sign a motion to be put to the vote at the Labour Party’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.A vote in favour at conference would compel the Labour leadership to accept a so-called “People’s Vote”. Sources told The Sun the motion may also demand Labour then campaign “to remain in the EU”.Some 130 constituency Labour parties (CLPs) are already though to be supporting the move.Critically the push is backed by union leaders – including TSSA chief Manuel Cortes. Sources claim Momentum co-founder Jon Lansmann is also supporting the idea.A source told The Sun: “An overwhelming number of Labour members and voters are fed up with Brexit. We believe a substantial number want the party to face up to Brexit extremists.”Jeremy Corbyn has repeatedly refused to rule out a second Referendum – with aides merely saying it is not current Labour policy.But Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer last month said Labour could back a ‘People’s Vote’ if MPs reject Theresa May’s final deal with Brussels.At the time, he said: “In those circumstances it seems to me the sensible thing is to keep all our options on the table.”Union powerbroker Len McCluskey – the head of Labour donor Unite – last month said he was “open to the possibility” of a second vote.Labour opens the floor to motions by party members and activists on the Sunday of its annual conference. A panel of party bigwigs select a shortlist of motions that make it to the vote.Jeremy Corbyn suffered a major blow to his authority three years ago when unions and the membership rejected a bid for a vote on the renewal of the Trident nuclear deterrent at party conference.THE Pound slipped to its lowest level against the US dollar in nearly a year as traders worried about the growing possibility of a No-Deal.Sterling was down more than 0.4 per cent versus the dollar at 1.287 — its weakest point since last August.The UK currency also plunged 0.5 per cent against the euro, reaching its lowest since October.But the Pound’s tumble lifted the FTSE 100, as multinational companies listed on the index tend to benefit when foreign currencies are stronger than Sterling.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rod liddle building green spaces opinion
story: If it goes ahead with this, it will be the greatest act of vandalism against the British countryside in 200 years.It will also cost the Conservative Party hundreds of thousands of votes — perhaps millions.Because the people who live next to our beautiful open spaces tend to vote Tory.And they like looking at trees and fields rather than a Barratt estate.This is a crowded country and becoming ever more so. We’re losing more and more of our natural wildlife. Our open spaces diminish daily.And now the Government is being forced into building countless millions of homes. Why?We’re told we have a housing crisis. You might find this puzzling when you consider the birth rate in Britain has been dropping, not rising.The answer, of course, is immigration. We’ve been letting in half a million people every year for almost 15 years.The politicians try to tell you it’s nothing to do with our housing crisis — but they are lying. Lying to themselves and to you.One top academic expert, Oxford demographer David Coleman, reckons immigration is 85 per cent responsible for the rise in the UK’s population between 2000 and 2015.And the other figures you might find a bit chilling.Did you know, for example, that a whopping 28 per cent of all births in the UK are to foreign-born women? And the figure in London is a staggering 60 per cent.If you find an indigenous British person in London, say hello to him for me and wish him the best. He’s the last of a dying breed. White Brits are a minority in our capital.It’s not just that. The birth rate for British people is 1.75. The birth rate for immigrants is 2.06. That’s a very big difference.So not only do we let in half a million per year, but they have more kids and so doubly contribute to population growth and the need for new houses.Oh, and the need for lots of other very expensive stuff, such as schools, hospitals, welfare benefits and so on.We MUST call a halt to immigration. The overwhelming majority of the population thinks we need much tougher controls.And there are many people who think that immigration has not made the country any better, but actually made it worse.Cut the numbers coming in to 10,000 per year and our housing crisis would begin to lessen, given that 300,000 or so people emigrate every year.A net decrease in the population would massively reduce the need for new housing.Because unless we do that, the bulldozers will be moving in. The fields, hedges and woodland will be ripped up. The roads will be laid and the peace and quiet shattered.And this will not be a green and pleasant land for much longer.Katie Price has just managed to avoid being declared bankrupt.She’s been given three months to pay off a whole load of creditors, plus a whopping tax bill.Everyone seems shocked that she has apparently blown £45million.But that body needs a lot of upkeep. She spends thousands every month getting her nails done so they look really chavvy.And then there’s the periodic scaffolding required to keep those vast mammaries aloft – plus a bit of pointing and retiling.The surprise to me was how in the name of hell she managed to amass £45million, not how she managed to spend it.For doing WHAT exactly?A woman on a flight from Valencia to London apparently “bonded” with a “hot guy”.Now Jo Lia has launched a Facebook campaign to trace the poor bugger.She says he was called “Joe” and looked a bit like Jordan Henderson. Hmmm. But can he pass the ball sideways just as well? I bet she didn’t find that out. Anyway, above is a photo of Ms Lia.So Joe, mate – keep your head down and stay off social media for a while. If I had that loon sitting next to me on a plane I’d spend the entire flight in the khazi.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn appeared on the Iranian-run Press TV to cast doubt on Israel’s right to exist.He used to get paid handsomely for his appearances on a network run by a hostile government which enslaves its own people.Meanwhile, more Labour anti-Semites have been crawling out of the woodwork.Here’s a suggestion. Clearly Labour has no intention of kicking out its Jew-haters.So I would suggest everyone in the party who ISN’T anti-Semitic get the hell out right now.And leave the party to the racist, hard-left rabble who are currently running it.The broadcaster Sandi Toksvig says that people mistake her for Tom Cruise.It’s easy to see why, isn’t it? Spitting image.Oddly enough, people often mistake me for the model Chloe Ayling.I even had the police round when she went missing because someone reckoned they’d seen her in Thornaby. But it was just me, nipping out for some fags.Our former Foreign Secretary is in trouble for having said that Muslim women wearing the full burka look like postboxes, or bank robbers.But that’s pretty much what most think, isn’t it?Boris was against banning the burka. But increasingly I think we should follow most of our European friends and outlaw the ridiculous garment in public places.Almost half of British 18 to 24 year olds don’t know when World War One took place, according to a survey.And hardly any of them could name the prime minister – David Lloyd George – who led us to victory.But it’s not really their fault, is it? Truth is, they’re not taught stuff like this any more.The history curriculum has been pretty much stripped of things which shows Britain in a good light, or British people being the victims of aggression.Instead, they learn very dubious arguments about slavery and colonialism.It’s a dangerous thing. When you lose a sense of pride in your nation, you also start to lose respect for its authority and its laws.And you raise a generation of perpetually whining airheads who understand nothing of the sacrifices made by Britons in the past.YOU see? They take their dieting really seriously up here in the North East. Pizza, chicken and chips. My missus took this pic, above, in a Teesside café.She once spent two weeks trying to find a salad in Austria, with no luck.The BBC is about to spend more than two million quid on a propaganda campaign to make you pay its licence fee.This is as opposed to the rest of its budget, which is spent on a propaganda campaign to convince you that all immigration is good, Israel is evil and Brexit a catastrophe.Fewer and fewer people watch the BBC.The licence fee has become an absurdity – an unjust tax which growing numbers of people simply refuse to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blokes boxer shorts dads higher chance
story: They produce more sperm than those who wear Y-fronts, briefs, or jockeys – and of a better quality.Experts say testicles function best at cooler temperatures and get too hot in most underwear.They suggest fellas make the “relatively easy” switch to boxers if they are trying for a baby.Medics from Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health, in the US, analysed samples from 656 blokes.They were aged between 18 and 56 and had an average BMI of 26 – mildly overweight.Just over half – 53 per cent – typically wore boxer shorts.They had 25 per cent higher sperm concentrations than those wearing other underwear.And they had a 17 per cent higher total sperm counts and 33 per cent more strong swimmers.Their sperm were also more likely to be correctly shaped.The most notable difference was between men who wore boxers and those who wore briefs.Study leader Dr Lidia Mingeuz-Alarcon said: “These results point to a relatively easy change that men can make when they and their partners are seeking to become pregnant.”The study, published in the journal Human Reproduction, is the largest ever into the effects of underwear on sperm.Commenting on the findings, Prof Richard Sharpe, from the University of Edinburgh, said: “Successful sperm production requires a temperature 3 to 4C below core body temperature.“This is achieved via a specialised blood cooling system and placement of the testes outside of the body in the scrotum.“It is well established that anything that interferes with maintenance of testes cooling is likely to impair sperm production and quality.“But the extent to which type of underwear worn might cause such interference has been a subject of debate for many years.“Wearing looser underwear and avoiding other sources of scrotal heating, such as hot baths and saunas, are easy adjustments for a man to take that might have a positive effect on his sperm.“This may increase the chances of achieving a pregnancy – although pregnancy success was not measured in this study.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nasa astronaut encounter alien like object revealed
story: Leland Melvin, 54, worked as an engineer on board Atlantis when he spotted the translucent item while orbiting Earth.He admits that NASA said the incident was just ice breaking away from the vessel.In a chat on Twitter with fans about his experiences in space he was asked if he had ever seen any aliens or UFOs.Melvin revealed that he had seen “something, organic, alien-like” in the payload bay of the shuttle when he was working with colleague Randy Bresnik.The astronaut said the object he saw was “translucent, curved, organic looking” – ending his tweet with an alien emoji.He wrote: “I have not seen [a UFO] in space or on the ground but thought I saw something organic/alien like floating out of the payload bay.Randy Bresnik and I called the ground to ask what it could be and it was ice that had broken off of the Freon hoses.Melvin was then asked if he thought NASA had just told him that to keep him calm, he replied: “Hmm I don’t think so, but you never know.He added: I was about to say Houston we have a problem but know everyone spins-up when those words are uttered from a space vehicle.”The Space Shuttle Atlantis flew 33 missions during its lifetime and was retired along with the rest of the fleet in 2011.

title: brits lie alcohol intake doctor advice
story: Only two in five Brits tell the truth when quizzed by medics about alcohol intake.The rest fib for a variety of reasons. One in five (20 per cent) never keeps track of how much they are downing.While 14 per cent are scared that the doctor will judge them.The same proportion matches their answer to NHS guidelines.Eleven per cent worry their drinking will be blamed for their medical problem.And ten per cent are embarrassed about the amount they knock back.The poll of 2,008 adults and 191 doctors by Direct Line Life Insurance reveals women under 30 are the most likely to lie.Doctors think a quarter of patients (25 per cent) have a mild drink problem and a fifth (21 per cent) are “highly dependent”.Drinkers risk liver disease, pancreatitis and other conditions.Direct Line spokeswoman Jane Morgan said: “Without all the correct information about your life-style, you may not get the right diagnosis or treatment.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gatwick love darling complaint
story: Bosses said the terms are unprofessional despite being widely used as friendly way of talking to someone.The ban was outlined in a memo by contractor Wilson James, which provides special assistance services to passengers.It stated: “If you do not know the name of the person you are speaking with please refer to them as Sir or Madam.“We are in a customer-facing environment and must remain professional at all times.”But the censure has not gone down well with staff, who accused bosses of over-reacting.One told The Sun: “How small-minded to write a memo like this. The words ‘love’ and ‘darling’ are not derogatory or unprofessional — they’re terms of endearment.You have to wonder about the customer who ­complained too.”Wilson James defended its ban. A spokesman said: “Courteous language is important and we strive to provide regular briefings and reminders to staff of how professional customer engagement should be delivered.”Gatwick officials would not confirm if they support the ban, but said: “We always strive to address each passenger in a professional and courteous manner.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: facebook digital wild west trolls sun says
story: These outlaws have long given up any responsibility for the digital Wild West they’ve created.Their platform is polluted from top to bottom, giving trolls free rein and letting every extremist group under the sun publish despicable propaganda.The previous Culture Secretary Matt Hancock was the first to genuinely talk tough to the tech firms and demand that they mend their ways.The new one, Jeremy Wright, must go further and force them to change, because they show precious little appetite to do it themselves.Yes, it’s vital that our privacy is protected. We’d never want authorities to have a free pass to snoop into our lives.But when cops are confident that the missing piece to a case can be found online, it is outrageous that web giants don’t work with them to investigate.They act as if they’re above the law.Let’s see about that.THE new Civil Society Strategy is better than its clunky name suggests.As a general rule, putting power in the hands of local people — rather than leaving it with far-off Whitehall civil servants — is usually a good idea.It is residents who know which roads need fixing, which bins need collecting, and which social care services are struggling.And for all the know-how of local councillors, too many are in safe seats and not solely motivated by serving their voters.Between plans for “citizen juries” and freeing up cash for community organisations, this should be a much-needed boost for local democracy — with the cash to back positive initiatives.The ironic thing is that it all sounds very familiar.It used to be called the Big Society.DAVID Jason reckons Del Boy would have been relaxed about Brexit.Of course he would. After all, South London’s finest never had much time for a racket — or at least, one he wasn’t running himself.And Trotters Independent Traders always understood that connections with far-flung markets were just as important as those next door — after all, it was New York, Paris, Peckham.It might even be an idea to send Del off to Brussels to negotiate.Let’s be honest: he wouldn’t cough up £39billion for a dodgy deal, would he?And if Emmanuel Macron asked for any more concessions? Au contraire, Monsieur President.When it comes to negotiations, he who dares, Rodders, he who dares…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teenager parasite eye tap water contact lens
story: Skye Wheeler, 19, from Camborne, Cornwall, lives in constant fear that the bug - which is still sleeping in her eye - could cause her to go blind, or even kill her.She was told the microorganism burrowed into her cornea after letting water get between her eye and contact lens when she was 14.It caused her to develop an infection, known as Acanthamoeba keratitis, which has developed into a chronic fatigue syndrome, also known as myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME).The teenager said: The Acanthamoeba Keratitis burrowed into my cornea and ate away to create snail trails around my eye.I was told it is found in tap water. The ultimate mistake was a droplet of water between my eye and my contact lens. It could blind me, or even kill me one day.Despite years of treatment, I still have this parasite in my eye.I am told that it is dormant. It goes into this stage to protect itself, picture it curling into a ball.We will never be able to tell whether it is dead or not or if and when it may reawaken so I have to live with the feeling of never knowing.Skye started to have symptoms of ME, an incurable condition, just a month after coming off the medication doctors prescribed to treat her eye problem.The neurological condition causes extreme exhaustion, pain, brain fog, among a variety of other symptoms.She said: The fatigue is like no other - I actually wish there was another name for it.You cant muster up the energy to put on foot in front of the other.You cant get dressed and ready for the day without a blackness descending over your eyes. You cant carry a conversation let alone even speak.The bottom of the line is that there is no energy there in the first place to channel through your body to all the right places. The only thing you can do is lie and exist.Skye added: My life has been ripped to pieces and then burnt down into nothing but ash and smoke. My life was planned out.I lay in the dark because of light sensitivity alone and waiting for someone to return home and take me to the toilet.My bed is my world. My bed is my support. It has seen me through endless days of torturous pain, fatigue and inner turmoil.Rosie Halsall, 17, from Liverpool, also suffers from ME and was diagnosed just aged nine leaving her wheelchair-bound.At her worst, she was unable to lift her head from her pillow, was spoon-fed and unable to sit for more than 30 minutes without fainting.She said: ME has changed my life. I cant sleep in my bedroom, instead in a downstairs room. Im sensitive to lights and sounds, so regularly wear sound reduction headphones and sunglasses- particularly on bad days.People dont tend to see the bad days, the days when Im crying in pain, when Im too exhausted to wear proper clothes, and the help I need from my parents with washing myself.Both teens have decided to speak out in support of Severe ME Awareness Day and to raise awareness of the condition.A spokesman for the ME Association said: It is an invisible illness. When you see us, we might not always look ill, but when our symptoms flare, the effects are obvious.It can feel like a constant flu, the smallest exertion can floor us, our bodies are painfully sore, restful sleep eludes us, light and noise are intolerable, and brain fog causes confusion.There is no known cure and no effective treatment.

title: beauty salon advertisement receptionist ocd
story: A jobs site posting said the ideal candidate for Saks Hair and Beauty Warrington, Cheshire, would be “extremely well organised (OCD)”.Obsessive Compulsive Disorder is a mental health illness. Saks apologised for any offence.But eagle-eyed job-hunter Suzanne Hancock said: “Hey Saks….I think you need to get your HR department to check over your recruitment ads as this is not OK.“OCD is not about being organised….”She then added a link to the NHS definition of the disorder, which is thought to affect up to 1.2m Brits including celebrities David Beckham and Leonardo DiCaprio.Saks Hair and Beauty Warrington then replied: “I’ll have a look at it first thing, my apologies for any offence coursed.”Saks runs a network of hair and beauty salons throughout the UK. The first opened in Darlington in 1974. In 1981, the brand launched its first franchises.Saks have been contacted for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: naughty good kids school fun day
story: Year 6 students at Arden Primary School in Bredbury, Stockport, had been looking forward a fun day including ice-cream and inflatables with families forking out £10 each to pay for the event.But while the well-behaved students - with the schools Always Badge - were allowed to play on inflatables first, others were made to stay inside and watch.The schools decision has been met with fury from parents.Melissa Jopling, who has an 11-year-old son, told Manchester Evening News: The ones without a badge have already been punished, so why punish them twice?We’re talking about things like not holding a door open for a teacher, or arguing at playtimes. My son had the badge but it was taken away when he was fidgeting in class but that was because they’d taken his fidget spinner off him.The 34-year-old mum - whose son Mika, seven, is still at the school - has launched a petition to get rid of the badges.Other parents have spoken out, with one writing on Facebook: Everyone paid the same amount to do the same fun day. How very wrong is it to punish a child on a fun day when they have already been punished beforehand. Even prisons don’t punish you twice.... imagine getting ten years for a crime and then two days before you get out they give you another ten years.”The schools head teacher Nicola Haddock defended the decision, saying all children had at least two-and-a-half hours on the play equipment.Ms Haddock said: The Year 6 fun day, funded by both parents and our Parent Teacher Association, is a celebration for all of our children. While the children rightly recognised for their continued good behaviour over the school year were given the first place on the inflatables, this was not at the cost of the other children. They had a choice of other activities and time on the inflatables and, with all of our pupils, had equal access to ice-cream.I have investigated the concerns from the parents who have approached the school, as I do with any parental concern, and responded to them personally apologising for any shortcomings they may have felt happened on this day. I will, as always, review the school’s practices in light of parents’ feedback.

title: treasure hunder darrell miklos ufo bermuda triangle
story: Darrell Miklos uses secret maps created by his ex-NASA astronaut pal Gordon Cooper to unearth shipwrecks in the briny deep.But during one of these trawls, intrepid explorer Darrell stumbled across huge mysterious structures that he thinks could change how we view our place in the universe forever.The huge unidentified submerged spaceship is covered in 15 unusual protrusions — which Darrell describes as unlike anything I have ever seen.Darrell, who will show off his other-worldly find on his Discovery Channel show Coopers Treasure, told MailOnline: It was also something that was completely different from anything that Ive seen that was made by nature.The mystery objects were found lying on the seabed near the Bahamas — within the notorious 1.3million km watery grave known as the Bermuda Triangle.It is the scene of countless strange disappearances of planes and ships — attached to which are curious tales that some discredit as myth but others say point to extra-terrestrial or even paranormal happenings.Veteran diver Darrell made his mammoth discovery during a hunt for the wreck of English ships related to the 16th century Brit sea captain Sir Francis Drake.But using maps designed in the 1960s by astronaut Cooper, Darrell detected more than 100 magnetic anomalies at an undisclosed location deep in the Caribbean waters. Describing his approach to his latest find, Darrell said: I was trying to identify shipwreck material based on one of the anomaly readings on Gordons charts when I noticed something that stuck out, that shocked me.He said the object has the appearance of a battleship with a steep wall from which five protruding arms stick out like cannons.Using special breathing apparatus to reach the 300ft-deep spaceship, Darrell said he and his fellow divers noticed that it did not appear to be man-made.And the fact it was covered in thick coral suggested the object — if it landed there from beyond our planet — did so hundreds if not thousands of years ago.Darrell added: Certainly nothing Ive ever seen based on my experience - and I have years of experience at doing this, weve identified multiple different types of shipwreck material - this doesnt match or look anything like that.Looking back at the Cooper charts, Darrell came across a puzzling note left by the former spaceman at the site of the structure — unidentified object.Now, Californian Darrell wants to investigate the mysterious site further — despite the risk he faces of being dubbed an alien conspiracy theorist.The Bermuda Triangle lies in a section of the North Atlantic Ocean which covers a vast area of 440,000 miles of sea.Its one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world, with vessels crossing through to get to ports in America, Europe and the Caribbean.Nicknamed the Devils Triangle it has been blamed for the disappearance of dozens of planes and ships over the past 100 years.When Columbus sailed on his first voyage to the New World, he reported a great flame of fire crashed into the sea one night and that a strange light appeared in the distance a few weeks later.However, reports of unexplained disappearances did not really capture the public’s attention until the 20th century when the USS Cyclops, a 542-foot-long Navy cargo ship with over 300 men on-board, sank somewhere between Barbados and the Chesapeake Bay.One of the most famous mysteries was the disappearance of Flight 19 when five Avenger Torpedo Bombers vanished over the Triangle on December 5, 1945.All 14 men on the flight disappeared without a trace and a Martin Mariner Flying Boat also vanished during the search with 13 men on board.At least 1,000 lives have been lost in the last 100 years. On average, four aircraft and 20 yachts go missing in the area every year.Theories about the Trinagles strange occurences include UFO abductions, a shield to guard the lost city of Atlantis and sinister secret government testing. He wants to remain neutral until he can dig up more evidence on what the structure could be and is hoping to have a third series of his Discovery show commissioned to help tell the story.Hopeful Darrell added: I want to see what it is, because it may be nature-made, just a freak of nature.But given its placement in this particular part of the Caribbean and given what Gordon has told me about visitors from another planet and the things that Ive seen, I think its definitely worthwhile investigating.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gazza paul gascoigne split art boss sara lovatt
story: Mum-of-two Sara Lovatt said last week that their relationship was early days but added that were having a lot of fun - but the couple have now gone their separate ways.Gazza posted this selfie with a caption confirming that he is now singlePaul Edwards The Sun4Mum-of-two Sara Lovatt has split for Gazza following a brief relationshipOn Twitter Gazza confirmed the split, saying: I’m OK single and find me a girlfriend please.He added: I’ve lost the love of my life my DAD he was my ROLE MODEL X.Mercedes-driving Sara owns the exclusive Antidote Art Gallery in Lutterworth.It was claimed she had been dating the former Tottenham, Rangers and Lazio ace, 51, for a few months and said the star - who has battled drink and drug addictions - is the best he has been for ages.The 49-year-old told the MailOnline: I was never a fan during his football days but I am now.Hes very handsome and really fit and tanned.Hes Paul to me and just a nice, funny guy whos had a tough time.She added: [He] is coping better than his fans are led to believe.Gazzas dad died in February this year but the star insisted at the time that he was in a strong place.And he said he managed to resist returning to drink despite the personal tragedy.The football legend said he last drank before entering rehab on December 2 last year.Just last month, Gazza admitted he still cries over his Italia 90 heartbreak when he famously blubbed on the pitch after receiving a booking which would have ruled him out of the final.

title: tom hardy helps mugger
story: The Hollywood superstar was hailed a hero when he sprinted after the crook, who crashed a stolen moped and fled in London.Screen hardman Hardy, 40, followed the teen thief through gardens and across a building site — before proudly announcing: “I caught the c***.”But Tom has now revealed that he has since reached out to the wayward youth to put him on the right track.Dad-of-two Tom told Esquire: “He must stand accountable for what he’s done.“But he’s got issues, and he’s in a bad way. Do we just give up on a 16-year-old?”The actor, who will star as Marvel anti-hero Venom to be released in October, also humbly played down his superhero antics that were revealed by The Sun.He insisted it wasnt much of a chase when he snared the young yob — adding: When I found him, he was in f***ing rag order.But witnesses said they saw Batman star Hardy vaulting over walls during his pursuit last April.Arun Pullen, 22, said: “It was mental - like he’d switched to superhero mode in an action movie.Two boys on the nicked moped had jumped a red light and smashed into a car.“Tom must have been walking down the road. He went off like a shot in pursuit and looked furious.If the kid had been dumb enough to resist I reckon Tom would have given him a good hiding.”Arun watched as the actor, who lives nearby in Richmond, South West London, hauled the runaway thief into a bus stop — and patted him down for weapons.He said: “The kid looked wrecked and in shock.“Tom Hardy’s clearly not a man you’d mess with. I think he even checked the kid’s ID before cops took over.”Arun said Tom used the C-word to describe the thief.He added: “I asked Tom what happened and he told me he chased him through my back garden and caught him around the block — but the route was like an assault course.”Tom, 39, told one onlooker: “This little s*** nicked something and now he’s got himself a ­broken leg.”The stolen moped carrying two men crashed into a £50,000 Mercedes at a busy road junction.Both thieves were injured. One was caught within moments but the other fled through gardens towards waste ground, where Tom caught up with him and made a citizen’s arrest.Two suspects were arrested on suspicion of theft and taking a vehicle without consent.Arun said: “Tom did the public a great service.”Girlfriend Kalisha added: “I’m a big Tom Hardy fan and there was no mistaking him. He looked as mad as he does on telly.”Tom Hardy’s spokeswoman declined to comment at the time.

title: oxford council orders parents remove paddling pools trampolines
story: Parents received a letter from Oxford City Council ordering them to remove the kids’ paddling pools from a communal garden because of health and safety.Residents in the council-managed flats blasted the move as ‘over the top’ for essentially plastic with water in.Ten-year-old Aaliyah Flynn, who plays in the garden with pals every day, said: Im so angry.If they come and take the trampoline away I’m going to get everybody to lay on it, then they can’t remove it.The council also told tenants to remove trampolines and kids toys by tomorrow – or face paying for the removal.In the order received on Monday, the councils tenancy management officer wrote that they understood parents “trying to enjoy the nice weather” but that the pools had to be removed for “health and safety and insurance purposes.”Chris Crawford and his wife Lynn, who have lived in the Hawksmoor Road flats for six years, said: The council have gone a bit over the top.They’re just plastic with water in.” Residents want to delay the removal until the end of summer so that their kids have somewhere to cool down during the scorching temperatures.“We don’t need the pools all year round, but we at least want them until the end of summer, and now we’ve heard this heatwave will be going on until October,” said Chris.In its letter the council said its tenancy agreement stated that residents must not leave any hazards or obstructions in communal areas, including personal items.It added that parents could take their kids to nearby parks to enjoy outdoor splash areas instead.But dad Chris added that one his children has ADHD meaning he cant walk to the park, and that it was easier to keep an eye on the kids when theyre playing in the garden.An Oxford city council spokesman said: We’ve had to ask people to clear the communal areas for health and safety reasons.The council would have a degree of liability in the event of any accident.

title: best perfectly timed pictures
story: These snaps show how sometimes a funny coincidence or perfectly timed click can result in something far better than you could have ever prepared for.From curious angles to heart-stopping moments, these images will leave you marvelling at how excellently the moment was captured on celluloid.And it does take a special kind of luck to snap up something so perfectly timed.Sometimes its down to perspective and sometimes its just perfect positioning resulting in a jaw-dropping optical illusion that turns a split-second into a lifelong memory.From the hilarious to the downright disastrous – here are our favourites.

title: weever fish uk beaches heatwave
story: The small venomous fish have been drawn to UK shores by the recent heatwave and lurk in shallow water.The creatures bury themselves in the sand for camouflage, making it hard for sun-worshipping Brits to spot them.If trodden on the spines unleash a powerful venom that can cause excruciating pain.Beau Gillet, an RNLI lifeguard supervisor, said the bites can pierce the skin and affects people differently.She said: Ive seen grown men cry from the pain and then a small child not be affected by it.Lifeguards in Cornwall have reportedly treated more than 70 people in just a week for the sting.Last month Charlie Gillett, a RNLI lifeguard supervisor, told Plymouth Live that the service had treated 17 people for weever stings in only one weekend.Now the RNLI has issued guidance on how to treat the fish’s powerful sting.The list, posted the RNLI Dover Facebook page, says that you should rinse the affected area with seawater before soaking in hot water for at least thirty minutes.According to the British Sea Fishing website, the sting causes swelling and inflammation, and even localised paralysis in certain cases.However, only two are found in UK waters – the lesser and the greater weever.The lesser weever is the type which Brits are most likely to come into contact with.They are aggressive predators, feeding on immature fish, prawns and crustaceans. The creatures have spines containing strong venom on their dorsal fins and on their gill covers.The species are mostly brown and around four to eight inches long. Stings from the creature were relatively rare, but a growing number have been reported in Plymouth, Cornwall and Kent.People have been known to become unconscious due to the venom – and even die.In 2001 jogger Carrie Kelly was knocked unconscious by a weever sting while out on Aberavon beach in Port Talbot.While schoolgirl Eve Austin developed a rare condition leaving her in a wheelchair after being stung by the fish on a family holiday in 2016.According to NHS Choices, if you are unlucky enough to get stung at the beach you should not pee on the area, cover it with vinegar or close the wound.It  recommends soaking in hot water and removing the spines from the skin with tweezers or a bank card. The effects of the sting should go within 12-14 hours, says the site.Lifeguard Beau recommends wearing swimming shoes to protect your feet.Alternatively dragging your feet along the beach is said to disrupt the sand and scare any hiding fish away.

title: eu prepared to let britain stay in their markets after brexit but only if theresa may continues to accept new eu rules for years to come
story: A Brexit breakthrough could be on the cards if the bloc agrees to a climb down and softens their red lines.The EU has previously said that letting Britain trade freely but not allowing hundreds of thousands of people to come to Britain, would be splitting up the blocs key pillars and have refused to accept it.Theresa May is still desperately trying to convince EU leaders to back her soft-Brexit Chequers plan to keep the UK close to the bloc after we leave.Reports from The Times suggested that the bloc could abandon their red lines in exchange for more Brexit concessions.They would expect her to replicate ALL new EU rules on the environment and customs rules - in addition to what shes set out on her white paper.The climb down could be discussed as early as next month at the meeting of all 28 leaders in Salzburg next month.But the move is set to infuriate Brexiteers - who have said they wont stand for any more giving in to Europe over Brexit.Commons leader Andrea Leadsom has said the Chequers deal is as far as Britain should be prepared to go before we walk away.Ministers have been stepping up their no-deal preparations in recent weeks as talks continue to stall between Britain and the EU.Trade Secretary Liam Fox said it was odds on to leave with no deal too - in a move which has spooked markets and seen the pound take another tumble.The withdrawal agreement has to be signed off by October in order to be ready by next March, when we officially leave the bloc.

title: bones discovered bristol skip broad street
story: Outraged locals had to call the cops twice - when the first officer on the scene laughed and said its just wood after eyeing the grim discovery.The Bristol Post claim the builders using the skip were working on the crypt of the nearby St Nicholas Church.Officers on the scene covered the skip with a thick black tarpaulin before taking the bones off to be examined in a lab.Barista Sam Ellis, 25, told the post: “A police car stopped down the road with sirens on. The policeman got a bone out of the skip, bashed it on the side and said ‘that’s wood!’ and drove off”Sam added: The guy who dumped it said he was working on renovations nearby. When he was digging it out it was clumped together, he thought it was pipes sticking out. When he threw it in all the soil fell off and we saw it was bones.”A spokesperson for Avon and Somerset Police said: “We were called to reports of a suspicious item - possibly a bone or bones - this morning at about 8.50am in a builder’s skip in Broad Street.“The skip is being used by builders who are renovating a property in nearby All Saints Lane area, where it is believed there was a cemetery.“The items will be forensically examined.”

title: boy whistle lodged throat
story: The four-year-old was taken to a hospital in India after two days of a persistent whistling cough.A video of the boy shows how he squeaked when he coughed, sounding exactly like Wheezy from Toy Story.Doctors took an x-ray of his chest and saw his left lung was hyperinflated - or blown up like a balloon.Hyperinflation is usually caused by a blockage in the airways or by certain lung conditions like asthma.To investigate further doctors performed a bronchoscopy, which involved inserting a tube down his throat and into the lungs.They were shocked to discover that the mysterious object blocking his bronchi, the air passage to his lung, was actually a toy whistle.It turned out the little boy had been playing with the small whistle and accidentally inhaled it, thats when the cough started, according to the case report published in the New England Journal of Medicine.Usually an object blocking the lungs would cause coughing and wheezing, but never a squeaking sound.A chest x-ray the day after the whistle was removed showed the boys left lung had returned to its normal size.A year later he is still in good health and his lungs no longer whistle.Its not uncommon for foreign objects to become lodge in airways or lungs.In 2017 an unnamed 47-year-old, from Preston, was referred to a respiratory clinic after complaining of being unwell and coughing up yellow mucus for a year.He had also been diagnosed with pneumonia two months earlier and had been a long-term smoker.Medics originally thought he had a tumour after an X-ray revealed a mass in his lung.A bronchoscopy was carried out to help doctors diagnose his condition.But they soon realised the mass was a long lost Playmobil traffic cone the man had swallowed on his seventh birthday.The 1cm cone was removed with biopsy foreceps.

title: url family rejected for council house after blowing inheritance
story: The Caradeuc family were turned down for a council house when officials discovered they had spent a quarter of a million pounds in just a year.Keith Caradeuc, 53, inherited the money from his fathers estate - worth around £500,000 - which he split with his brother.The dad-of-two admits he bought cars, moved to a nicer rented house, and paid for pricey weight-loss ops for wife Tania Caradeuc, 42 when they inherited the cash in 2015.But now the Caradeucs, from St Peter Port, Guernsey, say they have no money left to pay their rent.Former Sports Direct employee Tania said: In hindsight the money should have lasted longer.I was excited when I found out about the money because I came from a not very well-off family and Ive never seen money like that in my life, it was very overwhelming for both of us.But its ruined everything, in a way it was the worst thing that could have happened.Keith, a former delivery driver, and his brother sold their fathers house in June 2017 and shared approximately £420,000 from the sale which topped up their inheritance.The family had never seen so much money before and went on a spending spree - moving from their council house in St Jacques to a nicer property in St Martin.But their lavish lifestyle ended abruptly in March this year, just nine months after the house sale.Tania said the pair were shocked to realise they had spent around £250,000, including the inheritance money and the income from the property sale.She explained: I said, What do you mean all the moneys gone, it cant be?Her £30,000 surgery mostly took place in 2015 and included a gastric sleeve, tummy tuck and loose skin removal.She also had further surgery on her arms in late 2017.It was Keiths idea, she said. I lost ten stone, it was for medical reasons, my doctor said I have added years to my life, I wanted to make sure I was around for my children.Some people have acted negatively about that, they have said it was the easy way out, but it hasnt been easy.Keith and Tania, who have two children, say they are able to work due to mental or physical disabilities.The family still receive disability and carers allowance for one of their daughters who has a rare chromosome deficiency condition.But they dont have enough income to pay the rent at their new home, and have now applied for a council house.During the application the Caradeucs had to supply bank statements and as a result their application was refused due to depletion of capital.A spokesman from Employment &amp Social Security on Guernsey said it treated everyone who applied for social housing fairly.They said: When social housing tenants come into substantial sums of money, typically through an inheritance, they are required to vacate their States house.We communicate clearly with tenants who leave in such circumstances and inform them of the length of time that they are expected to accommodate themselves away from social housing.It is important that the system treats everyone fairly, given the demand for social housing.People unable to support themselves, in terms of day-to-day living and rent, are encouraged to apply for income support.

title: ohios squeaker election shows there is all to play for in us politics
story: They point to the high turn-out in urban versus more rural areas, traditionally good news for the left.They read with delight the ominous warning from the GOP supporting Congressional Leadership Fund super PAC."This remains a very tough political environment," it read. "Moving forward, we cannot expect to win tough races when our candidate is being outraised."Democrats knows they only need a net gain of 23 seats to take back the house. Many more than that are potentially in play.Republicans are right to be worried.But if we've learned anything from Brexit and Trump, it is that confidently predicting the outcome of votes is a bad idea.The United States has often been characterised as more closely resembling a patchwork of 50 individual countries rather than a single nation.Each has its own political obsessions, divisions, and issues.

title: us sanctions on russia bring political gain before midterms
story: Despite Donald Trump's history of charting a course often at odds with his own departments and agencies, especially on Russia, this time it is pretty safe to assume the president will toe the line.In part that is because there is political gain to be had here.The midterms are coming.A strong, decisive president, wielding power against adversarial nations like Iran and Russia, will play well with the Republican base.It is also useful that the new sanctions come at a time when Mr Trump is facing ongoing criticism that he is too close to Moscow, and as the constant drum beat of special counsel Robert Mueller's collusion investigation continues.Separately, there is also a broader issue relating to the necessity of dealing with existential threats.

title: gareth thomas dont sell wembley
story: NewsopinionGareth Thomas: Don't sell Wembley Stadium - tax the TV rights billions to fund grassroots football insteadInstead of flogging Wembley to fund grassroots sport, we need a 10% levy on TV rights, writes north London MP Gareth ThomasShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGareth Thomas MP15:11, 8 AUG 2018NewsopinionThere must be a better way to fund grassroots sport, writes Gareth Thomas MP (Image: Alex Morton)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email We shouldn't be selling off Wembley Stadium - the iconic home to England’s football team and a huge money-spinner.  The Football Association says it would plough a windfall into grassroots sport for 20 years. But there are other, better ways to do this. As the Premier League kicks off this weekend, it continues to receive at least &pound3billion from domestic and overseas TV rights. It’s not hard to see how England’s richest clubs have so much money to share around between themselves. So the FA should be demanding the government introduce a levy of 10% on the TV income Premier League clubs receive.  This would help nurture the next generation of Harry Kanes, Jordan Pickfords, and Kieron Trippiers. Grassroots football in England is, unfortunately, not as healthy as the Premier League's prize pot. Only one in three grass pitches are of adequate quality to play football in England, and last season one in six matches were cancelled due to poor facilities. Meanwhile taxpayers paid out more than &pound160million to build Wembley. So any decision to sell off this nationally important venue should not be taken before other alternatives have been exhausted. The Premier League currently puts just &pound100million into grassroots football- a pitiful contribution given how wealthy its clubs are.

title: its ridiculous anyone would go
story: NewsopinionIt's ridiculous anyone would go around talking like Boris Johnson - which is exactly why he does itBoris Johnson is the MP for Boris Johnson, and that's the only principle he's gotShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:23, 8 AUG 2018Updated12:31, 8 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe scene is a townhouse in north London. The honourable Member of Parliament for Boris Johnson is considering his next move. The Opposition is making headlines by chewing its own entrails over whether or not it likes Jews. The country is stockpiling food and medicines, while grass fires rage, cows go hungry and farmers talk of disaster. To make matters worse, he is being made to look incompetent by Jeremy Hunt, of all people, and Jacob Rees-Mogg is being spoken of as the next Prime Minister because he sounds clever. Grumble grumble and bugger me, Marina, but old Boris is benched! No-one is talking about Brilliant BJ. Damned impolite when I resigned on a matter of principle, having not displayed one iota of principle for the entirety of the 54 years I have given humanity the benefit of my existence. Well, I had a call on the telephoney-what-not the other day from Steve Bannon, you know, the man who looks like a suppurating tumour and got Donald Trump elected. He said I can take control of the news by saying mad and bonkers stuff, more mad and bonkers than normal anyway, not British bonkers but Trumpian bonkers. The fake news will faithfully report it all and the racists will love me, and all the racists-but-pretending-they-aren't will say they're supporting my economic policies.  So I asked the editor of the Waily Torygraph if they'd like me to write something that would get lots of attention, and they said they could do with something like that, and here it is, Marina old girl! If this doesn't get me on top of the news agenda for a solid week then nothing will!   Let me read it to you. I spent five whole minutes on it, it's really good. Listen.  Ahem. If you tell me that we do not have enough state control over what women wear, then I will man the barricades with you, comrades! Let us rip from Muslim women their headscarves, bare the bodies masked by burqas, remark upon the beauty or otherwise of faces covered by niqabs!  It is the sovereign duty of every Englishman, fwar fwar fwar, to see whatever bit of a woman they fancy. Especially if they've got dusky skin. Why, I regularly tell my wife to walk around in a balaclava purely so I can exercise my human right, guaranteed at the signing of Magna Carta, to jump out from behind a tree and rip it off again. And that's why we need to make the Queen walk around naked. Our monarch must set an example that British integration means women being told what to wear, and accepting that most days she looks like a knitted German egg cosy.  I am not in any way being racist. Did I say racist? I didn't mean to. It's what people will call me, of course, racist, but don't let us repeat the word racist in case it causes extra headlines about racism. So many items of female clothing are oppressive, and a truly liberal nation such as ours should not allow women of any race to totter along in high heels, thoughtlessly mimicking the billions of victims of Chinese foot-binding, nor the menace of winter tights that go all bobbly after a single wash and make them look like shabby French mime artists, coming over here and stealing the jobs of Ango-Saxon street artistes.  But let us not stop there, my brethren. Let us also call out the controlling nature of corduroy, the Nazi obsession with nylon, the perverted prevalance of polyester and wrongness of rayon. Nature made totty to titivate us, not to be hidden away! If this makes me a militant feminist then I am happy to confess I am one of the sisterhood.  And don't get me started on people who cover up their God-given bodies for religious reasons. The priesthood attracts paedophiles precisely because their vestments give them the perfect excuse to hide their true natures. And nuns! They're basically just angry penguins, aren't they? Penguins who flatten the wages of British Protestants.   And hair! Women shouldn't be allowed it, for it covers their skulls! Pluck out their eyelashes, epilate their eyebrows, render them clean of fuzz!  Say so long to saris. Wave bye-bye to baggy sweat pants, winter jumpers, 1920s vintage clothing, duffel coats and pyjamas. No woman needs them, and I say so in a spirit of weird and bullying adoration of the female form because otherwise we'll be overrun by half-drowned picaninnies.  In a spirit of gender equality I will also point out that not all men in crash helmets are acid-wielding murderers on a rampage, and of course we should not ban them as that would be an example of nanny state control. But if I make you worry about them, you'll be ripping helmets off little kids on trikes by the end of the week, won't you? Vote for Boris.  The hard truth everyone in this politically-correct world is too frightened to say is that it's simply ridiculous for people to choose to go around looking like letter boxes. Dogs urinating on them! story: News'Human' remains found in skip 'initially thought to be wood' by police officer 'who banged bone against bin'The officer walked off laughing saying 'it’s just wood'" before additional remains were found and police were called back, an eyewitness claimsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlex BallingerJoseph Smith13:49, 9 AUG 2018Updated13:52, 9 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBones have been found in a skip that was being filled with rubbish and debris from a renovation site. After the first bone was discovered a police officer banged it against the skip in Bristol city centre and left, thinking it was just a piece of wood, eyewitnesses claimed.  But officers were called back a short time later and a pair of Bristol Post reporters, including one on work experience, found additional remains at the property under renovation.  Police are now investigating to determine whether the bones are human or animal.  A police spokesman said the officer who responded to the initial call examined the first bone to be found, and found it difficult to determine if the very small object was bone or wood. There is believed to be an old cemetery at the building site, police added. A member of the public found the first remains in a skip in Broad Street, near St Nicholas Market, and alerted Avon and Somerset Police around 8am on Thursday.  Sam Ellis, 25, a barista at nearby Full Court Press, said: “A police car stopped down the road with sirens on. The policeman got a bone out of the skip, bashed it on the side and said ‘that’s wood’ and drove off.” Sam added: “The policeman walked off laughing saying ‘it’s just wood’. The guy who dumped it said he was working on renovations nearby. When he was digging out put it was clumped together, he thought it was pipes sticking out. When he threw it in all the soil fell off and we saw it was bones.”  Sam said that Kat North, the wife of the coffee shop's owner, had previously studied archaeology, and phoned police after examining the skip to tell them that it appeared to contain human bones. Police soon returned and put a black tarpaulin over the skip. Bristol Post reporter Joe Smith and Josiah Wong, who tagged along on work experience, went to the renovation site in nearby All Saints Lane, where they found more bones.  Josiah said: After taking a look at the outside of the building we found a wheelbarrow with three full refuse bags. Among the rubble we discovered more bone shaped items and informed the police officers nearby. Shop owners said the skip only arrived Thursday morning after being swapped for one which had been there for two days.

title: mum 39 who blamed prosecco
story: NewsMum, 39, who blamed 'prosecco' for repeating the same story at BBQ devastated to discover she has dementiaSarah Park has bravely spoken out to challenge stereotypes and put an end to the agonising uncertainty facing those who are living with young onset dementiaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBeth Abbit14:23, 9 AUG 2018NewsSarah has vowed to stay positive (Image: MEN/ WS)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 39-year-old mum was devastated to learn the real reason why she was repeating the same stories to loved ones - after thinking it was 'just the prosecco'. Sarah Park found herself retelling the same tales at social occasions - such as a family barbecue - but initially put it down to a 'couple of glasses' of the wine. However, she had also started putting cups away in the wrong cupboard and mixing up her kids’ washing at her home in Greater Manchester.  The subtle signs crept in until, finally, the mum-of-two was diagnosed with dementia , the Manchester Evening News reports.  Sarah, from Rochdale, has now spoken out about her condition and the vow she made with her husband Richard to stay positive.  She wants to challenge stereotypes and put an end to the agonising uncertainty facing those who are living with young onset dementia. As the first symptoms crept into her social life around 18 months ago, they also began to affect her professional life. While working as a senior cardiac physiologist, she started making uncharacteristic mistakes. To compensate, Sarah started getting up earlier for work with Calderdale and Huddersfield Health Trust. She would jump in the car at 5am for her drive over the Pennines to get to her desk early so she could spend longer analysing scans. “I thought I could work my way through it by doubling the effort and that worked for 12 months, so I kept plodding on - but then there was another mistake,” says Sarah.  “It was nothing major and it got picked up so no patient was ever at risk, but I noticed mistakes and I just could not remember why I had made them. It was horrible.”  At that point, Sarah told husband Richard ‘I can’t do it anymore’. “It wasn’t worth it,” she adds. “It was just one mistake, but it can make all the difference to someone’s health. “It’s sad because I loved my job, but the dementia was a bit of a problem – although I didn’t know it was dementia at the time - so I had to call it quits.”  Though she knew something was wrong, Sarah’s condition was repeatedly mistaken for depression by doctors who struggled to find the right answers. “They said I had depression and they focused on the work thing – ‘it’s because of work, it’s because of work’, they kept saying,” Sarah said. Richard had already started noticing ‘little things’ that gave him cause for concern. “It’s probably going back further than I realise - repeating stories on social occasions like a family barbecue which I put down to a couple of glasses of prosecco,” he says. “But then I noticed things at home a bit more – like putting cups in the wrong cupboard or mixing up the kids’ washing and there was the work situation.” Richard’s concerns were heightened due to Sarah’s family history. Her dad died of Alzheimer’s at the age of 40 and her grandmother also developed dementia. Initial scans and a normal cognitive test failed to provide definitive answers. But Richard, a structural engineer, said ‘he knew in his heart of hearts what was going on’ and the couple ended up at the Cerebral Function Unit in Salford.  “We said we wanted a second opinion there in January and within three or four weeks, Sarah was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s,” said Richard. Describing her reaction, Sarah says she was both devastated and relieved. “I was gutted it felt like a kick in the teeth. But it was also a relief that we finally knew what was going on,” she said. On the day of her diagnosis, Sarah and Richard returned to their home in Milnrow, sat on the sofa and cried. But their despair didn’t last long as the couple vowed to remain positive. “We’re not the type of people who will sit around feeling sorry for ourselves and we don’t want anyone else to do that,” said Richard. “We came back in the afternoon so the kids were away at school, sat down on the couch, had a hug, had a cry but dusted ourselves off and by the time the kids came back from school we were fine.” He added: “I took the kids to one side separately and told them about the diagnosis and how they would just have to support Sarah every step of the way. “And that’s what we’ve been doing – but we’ve still got to crack the whip and ask them to do stuff like tidy their rooms.” Along with their children George, 14, and Emily, 12, Sarah and Richard want to change social perceptions and prove it’s possible to live life to the full after a dementia diagnosis.

title: toddler twins rushed ae after
story: NewsToddler twins rushed to A&E after being stung on mouths by wasps during picnic with mumMum Amanda Muller, 34, says her little girl's lip ballooned and her brother's temperature spiked after they were stung by the insectsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPeter Craig10:04, 9 AUG 2018Updated10:20, 9 AUG 2018NewsLuca and Roma with mum Amanda Muller, left, and friend, Amelia Pykett, who were with them at the time (Image: GrimsbyLive/ WS)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A worried mum had to rush her one-year-old twins to A&ampE after they were both stung on the mouth by wasps during a picnic.  Anxious Amanda Muller says toddlers Luca and Romy were stalked by the insects while visiting a beauty spot in Louth, Lincolnshire.  She says little Romy's lip ballooned and Luca had a spike in his temperature after they were stung in the face, Grimsby Live reports.  She has now called for more warning signs at the scenic beauty spot where she claims families are being terrorised by large swarms. The incident occurred at Hubbard’s Hills, Louth.   Drunk US woman tells cops they shouldn't arrest her because she's 'pretty, thoroughbred and white'  Mum-of-four Amanda, who co-owns a dance academy, said: “We were there a couple of weeks ago and it was ace. So we thought we would all go again and took pack ups. But within half an hour I was in A&ampE with the twins. Luca and his sister Romy, who are due to celebrate their second birthdays on Sunday, were eating snacks. Wasps stung Luca on the top lip first as he munched Mini Cheddars. One then stung Romy on her bottom lip as she ate a ham sandwich. “The kids were not bothered by the wasps buzzing around them but we were wafting them away, said Amanda.  But it was like being stalked. They did not go away, even though you spun around. We moved to another spot but they still came for us. “There were other people stung while we were there. The mum is warning other families to be aware of the risk of wasp stings. “There should be more signs up to warn people and what to do if you get stung,” said Amanda, of Holton-le-Clay. A Hubbard’s Hills spokesman said signs warn visitors to be aware of wasps. Both Luca and Romy were treated at Louth County Hospital with anti-histamine and steroids. Most insect bites and stings are not serious and will get better within a few hours or days. Insect bites and stings will usually cause a red, swollen lump to develop on the skin. This may be painful and in some cases can be very itchy. The symptoms will normally improve within a few hours or days, although sometimes they can last a little longer. Wash the affected area with soap and water. Apply a cold compress (such as a flannel or cloth cooled with cold water) or an ice pack to any swelling for at least 10 minutes. Raise or elevate the affected area if possible, as this can help reduce swelling. Avoid scratching the area, to reduce the risk of infection. Avoid traditional home remedies, such as vinegar and bicarbonate of soda, as they're unlikely to help. But the invasion, due to perfect breeding conditions, has brought plenty of business to pest controllers in northern Lincolnshire. Vermfree owner, Luke Pomfret said he was responding to 50 calls a day and was taking out 10 wasps nests per day due to the impact they are having on households and businesses. Luke - who ironically is allergic to wasp stings - even responded to one wedding venue where guests were fearful to go out due to the swarms of wasps outside. Luke said: “It is unreal. I have never seen anything like it. People who have worked in the profession for over 20 years say they have never seen so many nests.” He added: “It was really poor last summer and I had about 20 nests. But now I am doing up to 10 a day.”  He responded to the Waltham home of Mike Chase who had two nests on his property. He told how he keeps watching out for apples falling from his tree in the back garden because wasps swarm over them within minutes. Try kicking one of those apples, and you would be in trouble, he said. Luke wears a protective suit because of his allergy. He was treated in hospital two years ago after being stung on his ankle. The 29-year-old told how he rapidly became very itchy all over his body and scalp and suffered hives throughout his body. He was treated in hospital. There are lots of things you can do to prevent an invasion and its often easier than dealing with a problem to get rid of them. You should regularly inspect your home for any nests developing. Look in your loft, shed, garage or under the eaves. Also check your garden. Nests will start golfball size. When the queen starts laying eggs, they will grow in size rapidly. You should keep bins away from windows and doors. It's best to empty and wash them regularly so wasps are not attracted to them. Check your home for any gaps or holes, particularly in the loft. You can put insect mesh over grille vents or air bricks to make it harder for them to get in. Keep sweet-smelling plants, which may attract wasps, away from your doors and windows. Why are there so many wasps? Wasps start appearing in the spring but mainly just the queens who are looking for a suitable nest site. But they start to run out of food around August and that’s when they go out looking for alternatives - normally all the sweet things we have on our tables and in our kitchens.

For 90 per cent of the year, we pray for sun – and when it appears, we don’t really know how to cope with it. The shops sell out of fans. The Met Office issues an emergency weather warning. People stop wearing clothes. And we all get very concerned about the state of the grass. But while most of us just moan, some people managed to find humour in the recent sweaty situation across the UK - and even came up with some genius hacks to cope. This was the state of play in Britain during the hot spell, according to Twitter:   1. No-one was doing any work  There’s pretty much nothing worse than trying to work inside an office during summer.
